docs.lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll found solid support for a government-run insurance plan, or so-called public option, that would compete with private insurers. Other surveys have found similar results. But what the public seems to prefer and what Congress plans to give them may not be the same thing.
docs.abstract: Latest New York Times/CBS News Poll found solid support for government-run insurance plan, but what public seems to prefer and what Congress plans to give them may not be same thing; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Are the health care commercials that are flooding the nation's airwaves reaching a point of diminishing returns? Nearly $100 million has been spent this year on commercials intended to influence the health care debate, including $30 million in August alone, according to Evan Tracey, founder of the Campaign Media Analysis Group, a research firm in Arlington, Va. ''In just the last 60 days, 49 different groups have aired nearly 100,000 TV commercials about federal health care policy,'' Mr. Tracey wrote recently in Advertising Age.
docs.abstract: Nearly $100 million has been spent in 2009 on commercials intended to influence health care debate, including $30 million in August alone, according to Evan Tracey, founder of Campaign Media Analysis Group (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: This is part of a series of primers on some of the basic elements of the health care legislation circulating in Congress. Earlier posts have explained how to compare health plans, and the concept of insurance exchanges.

headline.main: A Primer: The Public May Have More Appetite for a 'Public Option' Than Congress

docs.abstract: The public may have more appetite for the public option than many in Congress do.
docs.snippet: The public may have more appetite for the public option than many in Congress do.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thanks to everyone who took part in today's EconoQuiz.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee hearings on the health care legislation wrapped up for the weekend after Democrats decided to skip what was expected to be a high-octane debate over an amendment to add a government-run health insurance plan, or public option, to the bill.

headline.main: Senators Postpone Debate on Public Option

docs.abstract: The Senate Finance Committee adjourns without debating a public option.
docs.snippet: The Senate Finance Committee adjourns without debating a public option.

docs.lead_paragraph: By a margin of 52 percent to 27 percent, Americans believe President Obama has better ideas about overhauling health care than Republicans do, according to a national poll conducted by The New York Times and CBS News. And nearly two-thirds of the country supports creation of a government-run insurance plan, or public option. Read the full story.

headline.main: Times Poll: Public Leans Toward Obama Over Republicans on Health Care

docs.abstract: A national poll conducted by The Times and CBS News finds confusion over health care proposals but wide support for a public option.
docs.snippet: A national poll conducted by The Times and CBS News finds confusion over health care proposals but wide support for a public option.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the final day of the G-20 summit, President Obama and the leaders of France and Britain are set to unleash a foreign policy bombshell that could lead to even more heightened tensions in theWest's relationship with Iran.
docs.abstract: The G-20 gets permanent status on the last day of its current meeting in Pittsburgh, while the United States, France and Britain call out Iran for a secret nuclear facility.
docs.snippet: The G-20 gets permanent status on the last day of its current meeting in Pittsburgh, while the United States, France and Britain call out Iran for a secret nuclear facility.

docs.lead_paragraph: In my father's apartment building in South Jersey, the older tenants start drifting into the small lobby each day around 1 p.m., taking up positions on chairs and couches. The ostensible reason: The mail is about to arrive. The real reason: They relish a chance to schmooze.

headline.main: When the Neighborhood Is the Retirement Village

docs.abstract: States increasingly offer support services in NORCs: naturally occurring retirement communities.
docs.snippet: States increasingly offer support services in NORCs: naturally occurring retirement communities.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline.main: How Much Money Do Insurance Companies Make? A Primer

docs.abstract: An economist walks readers through the most recent income statement of WellPoint Inc. to explain how insurance companies make money.
docs.snippet: An economist walks readers through the most recent income statement of WellPoint Inc. to explain how insurance companies make money.

docs.lead_paragraph: “President Clinton found me waiting alone in his upstairs office called the Treaty Room, testing my tiny twin recorders on one corner of a massive but graceful Victorian desk.”
